sen.j: 本所（ほんじょ）は、日本荘園の荘園領主である本家および領家のうち、荘務を行う権限、すなわち荘園の実効支配権を有した者をいう。
sen.e: Among honke and ryoke, the both of which are the lords of the manor of Nihon-shoen (manor in medieval Japan), honjo was the lord that had the right to assert Shomu (management and control of encouragement of agriculture, taxes and so on in shoen), or in other words, had the effective dominion over the shoen.

Among honke and ryoke, both of which are the lords of the manor of Nihon-shoen (manor in medieval Japan), honjo was the lord that had the right to assert Shomu (management and control of encouragement of agriculture, taxes and so on in shoen), or in other words, had the effective dominion over the shoen.

Among honke and ryoke, both of which are the lords of the manor of Nihon-shoen (manor in medieval Japan), honjo was the lord that had the right to assert Shomu (management and control of encouragement of agriculture, taxes and so on in shoen), or in other words, had the effective dominion over the shoen.

sen.j: 平安時代後期に、在地領主が国衙などによる収公から荘園を守るため、中央の貴族や寺社へ寄進してその保護を求める寄進地系荘園が急速に増加した。
sen.e: In the late Heian period, there were rapidly growing numbers of the donated manors, which was the shoen donated to central nobles, temples or shrines by local lords asking for their protection of the shoen from shuko (confiscation) by kokuga (provincial government offices) and so on.
sen.cmt: 寄進地系荘園 - donated manors (定訳不明)
sen.e: In the late Heian period, there were rapidly growing numbers of donated manors, shoen donated to central nobles, temples or shrines by local lords asking for their protection of the shoen from shuko (confiscation) by kokuga (provincial government offices) and so on.

In the late Heian period, there were rapidly growing numbers of donated manors, shoen donated to central nobles, temples or shrines by local lords asking for their protection of the shoen from shuko (confiscation) by kokuga (provincial government offices) and so on.

sen.j: 寄進を受けた貴族や寺社がさらに上位の有力貴族・有力寺社へ寄進を行なうケースもあった。
sen.e: There were even cases in which the nobles, the temples or the shrines that had received a donation of the shoen further donated it to the more dominant nobles, temples or shrines in the upper-class.
There were even cases in which the nobles, the temples or the shrines that had received a donation fromthe shoen further donated it to the more dominant nobles, temples or shrines in the upper-class.

There were even cases in which the nobles, the temples or the shrines that had received a donation from the shoen further donated it to the more dominant nobles, temples or shrines in the upper-class.

sen.j: こうして形成された荘園支配体系の中で実効的な支配権を得たものが本所と呼ばれた。
sen.e: In the shoen governing system formed in this way, the lords who had effective dominion over the shoen were called honjo.
In the shoen governing system formed in this way, the lords who had effective dominion over the shoen were called honjo.
In the shoen governing system formed in this way, the lords who had effective dominion over the shoen were called honjo.

sen.j: 本家が本所となることが多かった。
sen.e: In many cases, the honke became the honjo.
In many cases, the honke became the honjo.
In many cases, the honke became the honjo.

sen.j: また、国衙や武士領主以外の荘園領主一般を本所と呼ぶこともあった。
sen.e: In some cases, the lords of the manor in general, except for the kokuga and the lords of samurais, were called honjo.
In some cases, the lords of the manor in general, except for the kokuga and the lords of samurais, were called honjo.
In some cases, the lords of the manor in general, except for the kokuga and the lords of samurais, were called honjo.

sen.j: 上記の本所から転じて中世後期（室町時代）には座の支配権者も本所と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: Deriving from the above meaning of honjo, a person who assumed control over za (trade association) also came to be called honjo in the later medieval period (the Kamakura period).
Deriving from the above meaning of honjo, a person who assumed control over za (trade association) also came to be called honjo during the later medieval period (the Kamakura period).
Deriving from the above meaning of honjo, a person who assumed control over za (trade association) also came to be called honjo during the later medieval period (the Muromachi period).

sen.j: 下って江戸時代等に全国の諸身分集団を組織化した公家も本所と呼ばれている。
sen.e: Closer to our own times, in Edo period for instance, a Court noble, which was the organization of groups of every walks of life throughout the country, was also called honjo.
sen.cmt: 一般的な｢公家｣の意味とは異なるように思われますが、そのまま訳しました。
sen.e: Closer to our own times, during the Edo period for instance, a Court noble, included in organizations of groups of every walks of life throughout the country, were also called honjo.
Closer to our own times, during the Edo period for instance, a Court noble, included in organizations of groups of every walks of life throughout the country, were also called honjo.

sen.j: また、本所が支配した土地を「本所」と称することもあり、日本各地の本所地名の由来となっている。
sen.e: Besides, some places governed by the honjo were also called "Honjo", and this is the reason why there are places named Honjo throughout Japan.
Besides, some places governed by the honjo were also called "Honjo," and this is the reason why there are places named Honjo throughout Japan.
Besides, some places governed by the honjo were also called "Honjo," and this is the reason why there are places named Honjo throughout Japan.

sen.j: 特に東京都墨田区の本所 (墨田区)が著名。
sen.e: Especially, Honjo at Sumida Ward, Tokyo Prefecture is famous for that.
Especially, Honjo in Sumida Ward, Tokyo Prefecture are famous for that.
Especially, Honjo in Sumida Ward, Tokyo Prefecture are famous for that.

sen.j: 平安時代中葉の10世紀後期から11世紀の頃、地方の有力農民である田堵（たと）による田地開発とその私有地化が活発化した。
sen.e: In the middle of the Heian period, around the late 10th century to 11th century, development and privatization of rice fields by locally influential farmers called Tato (cultivators) were e accelerated.

In the middle of the Heian period, around the late tenth century to eleventh century, development and privatization of rice fields by locally influential farmers called Tato (cultivators) were accelerated.

In the middle of the Heian period, around the late tenth century to eleventh century, development and privatization of rice fields by locally influential farmers called Tato (cultivators) were accelerated.

sen.j: このような開発田地の所有者を開発領主というが、その土地所有は法的根拠に欠け、国衙に収公される可能性も高く、非常に不安定なものであった。
sen.e: Owners of these developed rice fields were called kaihatsu-ryoshu (local notables who actually developed the land) but their land ownership lacked legal basis and was so unstable that there was high possibility of the shuko by the kokuga.

Owners of these developed rice fields were called kaihatsu-ryoshu (local notables who actually developed the land) but their land ownership lacked legal basis and was so unstable that there was high possibility of the shuko by the kokuga.

Owners of these developed rice fields were called kaihatsu-ryoshu (local notables who actually developed the land) but their land ownership lacked legal basis and was so unstable that there was high possibility of the shuko by the kokuga.

sen.j: そのため、開発領主の多くは、中央の有力貴族や有力寺社へ荘園を寄進することで、荘園の支配権・管理権を確保するようになった。
sen.e: This made many kaihatsu-ryoshu donate their shoen to dominant nobles, temples or shrines in central capital in order to secure the dominion and the management rights over the shoen.
This made many kaihatsu-ryoshu donate their shoen to dominant nobles, temples or shrines in central capital in order to secure the dominion and the management rights over the shoen.
This made many kaihatsu-ryoshu donate their shoen to dominant nobles, temples or shrines in central capital in order to secure the dominion and the management rights over the shoen.

sen.j: このとき、寄進を受けた者を領家（りょうけ）という。
sen.e: The receipt of such donations was called ryoke (a lord of the manor).
The recipient of such donations was called ryoke (lord of the manor).
The recipient of such donations was called ryoke (lord of the manor).

sen.j: 当時、天皇の代替わりの際に「新政」として荘園整理令が出されたり、また、国衙が荘園を認めずに公領へ編入しようとすることが多かった。
sen.e: At that time, Manor Regulation Acts were often enforced as 'a new government' when a new emperor ascended the throne, and the kokuga, who did not admit the shoen, often tried to incorporate the shoen into koryo (an Imperial demesne).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: At that time, Manor Regulation Acts were often enforced as 'a new government' when a new emperor ascended the throne, and the kokuga, who did not admit the shoen, often tried to incorporate the shoen into koryo (an Imperial demesne).

At that time, Manor Regulation Acts were often enforced as 'a new government' when a new emperor ascended the throne, and the kokuga, who did not admit the shoen, often tried to incorporate the shoen into koryo (an Imperial demesne).

sen.j: その結果、領家の権威だけでは荘園の所有が維持できないケースも見られた。
sen.e: As a result, in some cases, the authority of the ryoke alone could not maintain ownership of the shoen.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: As a result, in some cases, the ryoke authority alone could not maintain ownership of the shoen.
As a result, in some cases, the ryoke authority alone could not maintain ownership of the shoen.

sen.j: そこで、より権威のある皇族や摂関家へ領家から荘園寄進が行われることがあった。
sen.e: For that reason, the ryoke sometimes donated the shoen to Imperial family or Sekkan-ke (the families which produced regents), which had more authority than the ryoke.
For that reason, the ryoke sometimes donated the shoen to the Imperial family or Sekkan-ke (the families which produced regents), which had more authority than the ryoke.
For that reason, the ryoke sometimes donated the shoen to the Imperial family or Sekkan-ke (the families which produced regents), which had more authority than the ryoke.

sen.j: これらの最上位の荘園領主を本家（ほんけ）という。
sen.e: These lords of the manor at the top of the ownership chain were called honke.
These lords of the manor at the top of the ownership chain were called honke.
These lords of the manor at the top of the ownership chain were called honke.

sen.j: 本家・領家のうち、荘園の実効支配権を持つ者が本所（ほんじょ）である。
sen.e: Among the honke and the ryoke, the lords of manor that had effective dominion over the shoen were called honjo.
Among the honke and ryoke, the lords of a manor that had effective dominion over the shoen, were called honjo.
Among the honke and ryoke, the lords of a manor that had effective dominion over the shoen, were called honjo.

sen.j: 重層的な構成を取っていた荘園領主のうちで実社会においてもっとも有力な地位に立っていることが多かった本家が本所になることが多かった。
sen.e: Among the lords of the manor which had multilayered structures, the honke, which often occupied the most advantageous position in the real world, became the honjo in many cases.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Among the lords of the manor who had multilayered structures, the honke, who often occupied the most advantageous position in the real world, became the honjo in many cases.
Among the lords of the manor who had multilayered structures, the honke, who often occupied the most advantageous position in the real world, became the honjo in many cases.

sen.j: しかしながら、実際に在地における行政・司法の権限、すなわち荘務権を掌握していた者が領家などであったとしても本所と呼ばれていた。
sen.e: However, even other lords of the manor, such as the ryoke, were also called honjo when they actually assumed the authority of administration and administration of justice at their shoen, or in other words, the right to assert Shomu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, even other lords of the manor, such as the ryoke, were also called honjo when they actually assumed the authority of administration and administration of justice at their shoen, or in other words, the right to assert Shomu.

However, even other lords of the manor, such as the ryoke, were also called honjo when they actually assumed the authority of administration and administration of justice at their shoen, or in other words, the right to assert Shomu.

sen.j: 本所は、自らの権威を用いて荘園を国衙や他の荘園から保護した。
sen.e: The honjo protected the shoen from the kokuga or other shoen by exercising their own authority.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The honjo protected the shoen from the kokuga or other shoen by exercising their own authority.
The honjo protected the shoen from the kokuga or other shoen by exercising their own authority.

sen.j: その見返りとしてある程度の得分を荘園から得ていた。
sen.e: In return, they gained a certain amount of profit from the shoen.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In return, they gained a certain amount of profit from the shoen.
In return, they gained a certain amount of profit from the shoen.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代に入ると、幕府や武士の側から荘園領主を一括して本所と呼ぶ例が増えてくる。
sen.e: In the Kamakura period, there were more cases in which lords of the manor were collectively called honjo by bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) or samurai.
In the Kamakura period, there were more cases in which lords of amanor were collectively called honjo by the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) or samurai.
In the Kamakura period, there were more cases in which lords of a manor were collectively called honjo by the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) or samurai.

sen.j: 在地における実権を行使しえた本所の権力は大きかった。
sen.e: The honjo was granted extensive authority because it could exercise real power over their shoen.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The honjo was granted extensive authority because it could exercise real power over their shoen.
The honjo was granted extensive authority because it could exercise real power over their shoen.

sen.j: そのため、本所に対する年貢・公事などの各種奉仕・負担を本所役と呼び、荘園における荘民の負担の中でもっとも主たる地位を占めていた。
sen.e: Therefore, a variety of services and obligations against the honjo, such as nengu (land tax) and kuji (public duties) were called Honjo-yaku and regarded as the most significant among the burdens on people at the shoen.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, a variety of services and obligations against the honjo, such as nengu (land tax) and kuji (public duties) were called Honjo-yaku and regarded as the most significant among the burdens on people at the shoen.

Therefore, a variety of services and obligations against the honjo, such as nengu (land tax) and kuji (public duties) were called Honjo-yaku and regarded as the most significant among the burdens on people at the shoen.

tit.e: Honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor) law
Honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor) law
Honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor) law

sen.j: 本所は、荘園の実効支配権を有しており、荘園の運営に当たって、独自の裁判権を行使するようになった。
sen.e: The honjo, which had maintained effective dominion over the shoen, came to exercise its own jurisdiction over the management of the shoen.
The honjo, which had maintained effective dominion over the shoen, came to exercise its own jurisdiction over the management of the shoen.
The honjo, which had maintained effective dominion over the shoen, came to exercise its own jurisdiction over the management of the shoen.

sen.j: そのため、本来の法令である律令から独立した法体系が形成されていき、これを本所法（ほんじょほう）という。
sen.e: As a result, a legal system independent from the Ritsuryo codes, which was the primary law, was developed to form a new legal system called honjo law.
As a result, a legal system independent from the Ritsuryo codes, the primary law, was developed to form a new legal system called honjo law.
As a result, a legal system independent from the Ritsuryo codes, the primary law, was developed to form a new legal system called honjo law.

sen.j: 荘園で紛争が生じたときは、政所などといった本所の家政機関において裁判が開かれ、紛争当事者や本所の関係者が出席した。
sen.e: In the event of any dispute arising in the shoen, trial was held at the honjo's domestic governing institutions such as Mandokoro (Administrative Board), and persons mainly concerned with the dispute and officials of the honjo were participated in it.

In the event of any dispute arising in the shoen, a trial was held at the honjo's domestic governing institutions such as Mandokoro (Administrative Board), and persons mainly concerned with the dispute and officials of the honjo participated.

In the event of any dispute arising in the shoen, a trial was held at the honjo's domestic governing institutions such as Mandokoro (Administrative Board), and persons mainly concerned with the dispute and officials of the honjo participated.

sen.j: 裁判に際して適用された本所法は、律令の系統を引く公家法や現地の慣習法などから成り立っていた。
sen.e: The honjo law, which was the applicable law in such cases, consists of court noble law, which was a descendant from the Ritsuryo codes, local common law and other laws.
The honjo law, which was the applicable law in such cases, consisted of court noble law, descendant from the Ritsuryo codes, local common law, and other laws.
The honjo law, which was the applicable law in such cases, consisted of court noble law, descendant from the Ritsuryo codes, local common law, and other laws.

sen.j: 本所法による刑罰には、拘禁や追放などの自由刑のほか、財産没収などの財産刑があった。
sen.e: The honjo law inflicted a variety of punishments, including the punishment by seizing assets, such as asset forfeiture, as well as the punishments by imprisonment or curtailment of liberties, such as intern or banishment.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The honjo law inflicted a variety of punishments, including punishment by seizing assets, such as asset forfeiture, as well as punishment by imprisonment or the curtailment of liberties, such as internment or banishment.

The honjo law inflicted a variety of punishments, including punishment by seizing assets, such as asset forfeiture, as well as punishment by imprisonment or the curtailment of liberties, such as internment or banishment.

sen.j: しかしながら、斬刑などの生命刑・傷害刑はほとんど見られなかった。
sen.e: However, the death penalty and the punishment that involved pain, such as the capital punishment that involved using a blade, were rarely executed.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the death penalty and punishment that involved pain, such as the capital punishment that involved using a blade, were rarely executed.
However, the death penalty and punishment that involved pain, such as the capital punishment that involved using a blade, were rarely executed.
